bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 7, 1940

div1.p: Kean is eager to meet with Hench to discuss yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 7, 1940
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
June 7 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
My dear Doctor
div1.p:
I have your letter of the
4th inclosing the your list of
questions and am glad to get both
the 17th will be entirely convenient
to see you and I will look for -
ward to your visit with pleasure
I have a foolish old pump, which
goes on a fibrillation spree several
times each month, but I will
use what influence I have with
it to have it behave on that day.
It does not not require more than
one day in bed and two or three
cat-units of digitalis, to bring it down
AC
K
2
to good behavior.

I hope that you will remember that
the Army and Navy Club at 17th &
I streets (Farragut square) will be
available if you care to take a
room there. It is cheaper than a
hotel and I think you will find
it pleasanter than the very crowd
ed hotels are.

With regard to the addresses of Mrs
Reed and her son Gen. W. L. Reed
her address is Blue Ridge Summit
Md. and his is Room 406, the
Winder Bldg. Washington, D.C.
Mrs Lazear was living some years ago
in Berkeley California, but we can
easily ascertain her present address
from the Pension Office in this city.
I wish that all your questions could be
3
answered with the ease and finality
of these addresses, but we can I
think get some light on most of them.

At any rate it will be pleasant
to talk over this famous episode
of so many - nearly forty-years ago.

I was at the University of Va for a
couple of days two weeks ago and
had a little chat with our friend
Mr. Clemons at the Library. I was inter-
ested to know that you have a
brother in the History faculty there.

closer.seg:
P.S. you need not fear to trespass on
my time. I am a semi - invalid
with plenty of it at the disposal
of my friends, as long as they will come
to me.
